speaker: Frasier
text: Okay, dad.  Now, you've seen the executive offices, the advertising offices and the lunchroom.  And we now finally come to the sanctum sanctorum: my studio. [_points to his picture on the wall_] You might recognize that handsome rogue over there.

speaker: Martin
text: Wow.  Your head photographs even bigger than it is.

speaker: Frasier
text: Very droll.  Get in. [_opens door and enters recording studio_] This is what we in the radio game call "The Booth."  It is here That I sit, day after day, and dispense the advice that helps the emotionally distraught through their troubled lives.

speaker: Martin
text: [_checking window_] Do you suppose this stuff's bulletproof?

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, you know, you could have gone home after lunch.  I just brought you here because I thought you'd enjoy it. [_Martin goes to press a button_] NOW DON'T TOUCH THAT!  It's a very sophisticated piece of electronic equipment!

speaker: Martin
text: What is it?

speaker: Frasier
text: I have no idea, Roz told me never to touch it!  You see dad, the usual procedure begins with...

speaker: Martin
text: [_into mike_] Testing!  Testing!

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Testing.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, dad, look, let's just go into Roz's booth, okay?  You can touch anything you want to in there.

speaker: Roz
text: Hey, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, hello Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Hi, Mr. Crane.

speaker: Martin
text: Hi.

speaker: Roz
text: What brings you here?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I'm just showing dad around, then he's gonna sit and listen to the show.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, it's kinda like payback for when Frasier and Niles were kids.  I used to take them to the police station and show them where I worked.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, he made a big game of locking us in one of the cells and pretending to lose the key.

speaker: Martin
text: I was just joking with them, I knew they weren't scared.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well no, we weren't really scared, although after a while we did become quite hungry.

speaker: Roz
text: Hey Frasier, could you lend me ten bucks?

speaker: Frasier
text: Did you leave your wallet home, or something?

speaker: Roz
text: No, I gave the last of my money to this poor guy down in front of the building.  He's an Australian tourist, he lost his wallet and he just needed ten dollars...

speaker: Martin
text: So he could take a cab to the Australian Consulate before it closes?

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah.  How'd you know?

speaker: Martin
text: There is no Australian Consulate in Seattle.

speaker: Roz
text: Ooh.  That poor guy!

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, it's a scam.  He scammed you.

speaker: Roz
text: No, this guy was for real, honest.  He even said...

speaker: Martin
text: "If you give me your address, I'll send you the money back with interest."

speaker: Roz
text: [_realizing_] God, I'm an idiot.

speaker: Martin
text: No, don't feel bad.  These guys are professionals. [_presses the fast forward button on a reel-to-reel recorder_]

speaker: Roz
text: [_coming to rescue_] DON'T TOUCH THAT!

speaker: Martin
text: What is this place, a radio station or a nuclear missile site? Now, listen Roz, don't feel bad.  I was a cop for thirty years, and they could still fake me out once in a while. These guys are professionals, they know what to do.

speaker: Frasier
text: Especially if you're an easy mark like Roz.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, the criminal mind is more complex than you think.  They can fool you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, by all means dad, lecture me on the complexities of the human mind.  Are you forgetting that I graduated with honors from Harvard in Psychosocial Behaviorism?

speaker: Martin
text: I know, I was at your graduation.  Impressive bunch.  A car backfired and half of them wet their gowns.

speaker: Frasier
text: It sounded louder on the dais!  All I'm trying to say is, if it were me on the street, I wouldn't have been fooled.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, you think because of your book smarts, that you can spot a crook just like that, huh?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well if I can't, I'm in the wrong business.

speaker: Martin
text: You want to put your money where your mouth is?

speaker: Frasier
text: What do you mean?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I've got three people coming over for poker tonight. Two of them are cops, the third one's done time in jail. I'll bet you five bucks you can't tell which one's the ex-con.

speaker: Roz
text: Hey, can I get in on the action?

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course you can.

speaker: Roz
text: Great.  Ten bucks on your dad.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, you're just itching to give your money away today, aren't you?  All right, you're both on.  But I think you're underestimating me.  What truffles are to pigs, so are these charlatans and pettifoggers to my mental acuity.

speaker: Martin
text: We didn't know better back then.  His mother smoked during pregnancy. **PICK A CON, ANY CON**  _Scene B: Frasier's residence. Frasier is lighting the fire while Martin sets up the poker table. Daphne enters._

speaker: Daphne
text: So, who are these people coming over tonight?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, just some of dad's old friends from the precinct.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah well, if we're having company, someone should have been cleaned up.  Because someone hasn't been smelling so fresh lately.  Because someone is long overdue for a tub.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, I took a shower this morning.

speaker: Daphne
text: You know I was talking about Eddie.  He's long overdue for a...

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, don't!  Don't say that word.

speaker: Daphne
text: What word?

speaker: Martin
text: B-A-T-H.

speaker: Frasier
text: When he yawns it may smell like swamp gas, but his spelling's improving.

speaker: Daphne
text: I've made meatball sandwiches, pepperoni pizzas and uh, little sausage rolls.  Will you be needing anything else?

speaker: Frasier
text: The number of the nearest gastroenterologist. [_opens door_]

speaker: Martin
text: Hey guys, come on in. _Martin's three friends enter: a heavyset man in his fifties (Frank), a woman of the same age (Linda), and a younger man (Jimmy).  They say hi._

speaker: Martin
text: These are my poker pals.  This is Linda, Frank and Jimmy.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_shaking hands_] Linda, Frank, Jimmy.

speaker: Martin
text: This is my son, Frasier.  Throw your coats on the couch. [_Frasier scrutinizes them_] Kinda hard to tell, isn't it? They all look like they did time.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, my dad tells me he's filled you in on our little bet. Now the ground rules for tonight are that I'm not allowed to ask you any questions directly about your line of work, but whatever questions I do ask, you must answer truthfully.

speaker: Frank
text: All I want to do is play cards.

speaker: Jimmy
text: Great place you've got here, Martin.

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, thanks.

speaker: Frasier
text: Actually, it's mine.

speaker: Jimmy
text: Boy, you must do pretty well on that radio show of yours. What is this place, about two thousand square feet?

speaker: Frasier
text: About.  Hmm... that's interesting, you noticed the space. Most people mention the view and the high ceilings, but you, you mentioned the space.  It's almost as if you'd spent some time living in a cramped, confining, tight area.

speaker: Frank
text: So you've been to Jimmy's apartment, huh?

speaker: Daphne
text: [_comes in from the kitchen with a tray of beers_] Hello there.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh hi, Daphne.  This is Daphne Moon, these are my friends, Linda, Frank, Jimmy.

speaker: Frank
text: Very pretty name.  Do people call you Daffy for short?

speaker: Daphne
text: Not twice.  Well, it's nice to meet all of you.  Here you go, I've got beers for everyone.

speaker: Frank
text: Still drinking the Ballantines, I see.

speaker: Linda
text: Yeah.  When you kick off, that company's going down the tubes.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, yeah.  Many's the time I come home to see cans of them, lined up one after another on the coffee table, like little tin soldiers they are...

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, thanks a lot, Daphne.  Don't you have a dog to wash?

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I suppose I do.  Of course, I have to catch the little bugger first.  Oh, [_taking can of beer_] maybe one of these would help.

speaker: Jimmy
text: Hey, beer's not good for dogs.

speaker: Daphne
text: No, but it's super for me. [_exits_]

speaker: Jimmy
text: Marty, she's pretty nice.

speaker: Linda
text: Yeah, and sexy too, you dirty old man!

speaker: Martin
text: Oh...

speaker: Frasier
text: Interesting... you find her attractive, do you?

speaker: Linda
text: Sure, don't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, but I mean, attraction to one's own sex is a not uncommon result of long-enforced periods of time spent exclusively in their company.

speaker: Martin
text: Wow, Frasier.  I may have underestimated you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Really?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, you're making a bigger jackass of yourself than I thought.

speaker: Jimmy
text: [_starting game_] High card deals.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, we could really use some music.  Anybody play the harmonica?

speaker: Frank
text: All right, my deal.  Dollar in to start, five card draw, jacks or better to open and the three raise maximum.

speaker: Martin
text: Sure you don't want to play, Fras?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, no-no-no-no-no, I'll just take this time to observe the triumvirate.  I believe in my considerable education, my years of study and not to mention, well... alright, let's say it, my God-given gift to intuit.

speaker: Frank
text: This is the kid who used to get his head flushed in the toilet, right?

speaker: Frank
text: Okay, I call.  What do ya got?

speaker: Linda
text: Full boat, aces up.

speaker: Frank
text: Damn it!  That's another one.  I'm losing my shirt here.

speaker: Daphne
text: Would somebody mind giving me a hand with the coffee?

speaker: Jimmy
text: Yeah.  I'll give you a hand.

speaker: Daphne
text: Come along then.

speaker: Jimmy
text: I really like your accent.  Where are you from?

speaker: Daphne
text: Manchester.

speaker: Jimmy
text: Manchester.  That's where the Beatles are from, right?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, no-no.  You're thinking Liverpool.

speaker: Jimmy
text: Then who's from Manchester?

speaker: Daphne
text: No-one.  That's why I live here now.

speaker: Martin
text: [_to Frasier_] You've been awfully quiet there.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry, dad.  Just been observing.

speaker: Martin
text: No no, don't apologize, it was a compliment.

speaker: Frasier
text: Frank's an interesting study, isn't he?  Temper, loner, a bit unsocial.  Almost a stereotypical portrait of a man who's spent his entire life behind bars.

speaker: Frank
text: [_examining one of Frasier's objets d'art_] This dish a Lalique or a Steuben?

speaker: Martin
text: They had no spots open in the prison laundry, he worked in fine china and glassware.

speaker: Frank
text: [_to Linda_] Here you go, big winner.  Buy yourself something pretty and frilly.

speaker: Linda
text: Sorry Frank, I can't hear you.  I've got your money stuck in my ears.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I guess there's only one thing left.  How about it, Fras?  You figured it out yet?

speaker: Frasier
text: Actually, I believe I have.  Shall we step into the drawing room?  Please have a seat.

speaker: Martin
text: Okay, Sherlock.  You've got center stage.

speaker: Frasier
text: I have sketched an accurate psychological profile of each one of you.  And in so doing I have come to the incontrovertible conclusion that the criminal among us can only be... FRANK!

speaker: Martin
text: Wrong.  Frank's a highly decorated undercover cop.

speaker: Frasier
text: Exactly!  Just a little too obvious, you know.  The broken vocabulary, the jailhouse pallor, the underdeveloped social skills...

speaker: Frank
text: Hey.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_to Martin_] So, you tried to use psychology against me, did you?  Threw a gender bender at me.  Thinking I'd just assume that a felon would naturally be a man.  Well, I'm on to your little game, mister.  The criminal among us is indeed, the very wily Linda!

speaker: Linda
text: Nope.

speaker: Frasier
text: JIMMY!

speaker: Martin
text: Hey.  You're right.

speaker: Frasier
text: Damn it... you seem like such a nice guy.

speaker: Jimmy
text: I am a nice guy.

speaker: Martin
text: He was voted most congenial in his cellblock.

speaker: Jimmy
text: Sorry, doc.  I'm afraid you owe your old man five bucks.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yeah, I'm afraid I do. [_searches in his pockets for his wallet_]

speaker: Jimmy
text: Oh. [_giving Frasier his wallet back_] You'll probably use this.

speaker: Linda
text: Well, it's been a lot of laughs, but it's getting late.  We better get going.

speaker: Frank
text: Yeah, you're right.  Thanks a lot, Marty.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, yes.  Great.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's been very pleasant.  You'll all come again, any time you like. [_to Jimmy_] Hopefully when we're here, of course.

speaker: Frank
text: Goodnight, Marty,

speaker: Martin
text: See ya.

speaker: Jimmy
text: Next week, Marty.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, yeah.

speaker: Frasier
text: Jimmy.  Boy, who woulda thought?  How do you even know that guy, dad?

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, he was a jailhouse snitch, he helped us out a couple of times.  Right, he's great company, but I wouldn't trust him for a second if he wasn't surrounded by cops.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_who's come in to clear table_] Who's a jailhouse snitch?

speaker: Martin
text: Jimmy.

speaker: Daphne
text: Jimmy's an ex-con?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_handing over five dollars_] Well, you certainly made your point. I feel stupid as hell.

speaker: Daphne
text: I feel rather a fool meself.

speaker: Martin
text: Why would you care, one way or another?

speaker: Daphne
text: Because... I've agreed to go out with Jimmy tomorrow night.

speaker: Martin
text: You did what?!

speaker: Daphne
text: He asked me if I'd like to go out for drinks with him to a place called the Topaz Room, meet some of his friends.  It sounded harmless enough.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, it's out of the question!  You're gonna have to call him and cancel!

speaker: Daphne
text: But you said yourself he was fun to spend time with.

speaker: Martin
text: I said DO time with.  No, no.  You just can't go.  Case closed, that's all there is to it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, excuse me, if I can interrupt that self-righteous policeman mentality for a second, don't you believe in second chances?

speaker: Martin
text: I did.  Then we had Niles.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I believe that when a man has paid his debt to society he deserves a fresh start.  I see no harm in her going out with him once.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I do!  She's not going.

speaker: Frasier
text: I say she is.

speaker: Daphne
text: Excuse me?  Gentlemen?  But might I interject one tiny little thought into this conversation?

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course, Daphne.

speaker: Daphne
text: BELT UP!  BOTH OF YOU!  It may have escaped your notice, but I happen to be a grown woman, and nobody has told me whom I might or might not date since I was a schoolgirl. And I didn't listen then.  Now, when I've quite made up my mind about what I plan to do about Jimmy, I'll let you know. But right now, I'm going to my room.  You two hens have wasted enough of my time.

speaker: Frasier
text: That would have been a very dramatic exit, if only her room was down that hall.

speaker: Martin
text: I still don't think she should be going out with that guy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, don't worry, she won't.

speaker: Martin
text: How do you know?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, because she has too much respect for your opinion. She won't go against your wishes if I'm any judge of character.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, dear God.  _End of Act One.  Act Two.  Scene A: Cafe Nervosa. Frasier and Niles are ordering._

speaker: Niles
text: [_to waiter_] I'll have a decaf latte, and please be sure to use skim milk.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'll have the same.

speaker: Waiter
text: Got it. [_to barista_] Two Gutless Wonders!

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you. [_to Frasier_] Certainly playing fast and loose with his tips for a man who drives a van.  Oh, oh-oh-oh, Frasier. How was your encounter with dad's poker buddies last night?

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah...

speaker: Niles
text: I must tell you - the picture of you trying to make conversation with dad's blue-collar cronies all evening is priceless.   When I told Maris about it, it was all she could do to keep her eyes from dancing.

speaker: Frasier
text: Actually, it was really rather interesting.  You know, one of them actually did time in prison for fraud?

speaker: Niles
text: Good lord!  What was he like?

speaker: Frasier
text: Actually, he was quite personable.  You know dad, he's so judgmental.

speaker: Niles
text: He is, and I've often condemned him for it.

speaker: Frasier
text: For some reason, you know, just because the man was in prison he seems to have marked him for life.

speaker: Niles
text: It's ridiculous.  Not all criminals are recidivists.  I've seen many cases where after they've paid their debt to society they've gone on to lead productive lives.  Dad's just being narrow-minded.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hmm.  Yes, I almost had to sedate him when Daphne announced that she was going to go out with him.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, I hope you're just yanking my giggle chain.

speaker: Frasier
text: What do you mean?

speaker: Niles
text: You're telling me that you're letting this English rose be sullied by some sociopath?

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, he passed bad checks.  He's not a sociopath.

speaker: Niles
text: He's a degenerate who should be put away forever!

speaker: Frasier
text: You haven't even met him.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, for God's sake, they're all depraved animals!

speaker: Waiter
text: [_bringing over coffee_] Here's your coffee.  Anything else?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, the check please, and quickly.  Frasier, we've got to rescue her!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Niles, Niles, just sit down and relax, for God's sakes. You're being irrational.

speaker: Niles
text: Don't you DARE call me irrational!  You know that makes me crazy!

speaker: Frasier
text: Now, Niles.  Listen, I think Jimmy's a perfectly nice guy. And besides, Daphne can take care of herself.

speaker: Niles
text: I don't care, I'm going after her. [_gets up and puts on his coat_] I'm not without resources.  My Tae Kwon Do instructor tells me I'm just two moves away from becoming quite threatening!

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, just listen to me for a second.  You know perfectly well that she'll resent any interference.  Now, you want to make a fool of yourself, go right ahead, but don't ask me to join you.

speaker: Niles
text: That's fine.  Just tell me where they went.

speaker: Frasier
text: Someplace called the, uh, the Topaz Room.

speaker: Waiter
text: [_who's brought the check_] The Topaz Room?  I thought the cops shut that place down after the last shooting.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'll drive!  _They exit, forcefully.  FADE TO:_  **ODDBALL IN THE CORNER POCKET**  _Scene B: The Topaz Room, a gritty bar. Daphne is playing pool with the regulars.  Her opponent (Leo) plays and misses the eight ball._

speaker: Leo
text: Your shot, girlie. _Daphne leans over the table to line up her shot.  The other patrons try to get a good look at her bottom._

speaker: Leo
text: But before you take that shot, why don't we make this a little more interesting?  All you have to do to win is run those last five balls.  So what do you say we double our bet?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, well.  I might as well.  I never really have understood this game. [_lines up_] Never understood it, when I started playing with me older brothers, at the age of six. [_clunk_] And I never understood it during all my formative years, spent mostly in the pool halls of Manchester. [_clunk_] Playing in local competitions and club tournaments. [_clunk_] Winning cup after cup after cup.  Until our poor dad had to convert the pantry into a trophy room. [_clunk_] And I can't really claim to understand it - eight ball in far corner - even today. [_clunk_] But I certainly do enjoy it. [_collects her winnings to the applause of the customers_] Thank you, gentlemen.  And now if you'll excuse me, I'm going to attempt to use the ladies room without touching anything. _She exits to the ladies room just as Frasier and Niles enter, stop and look around._

speaker: Frasier
text: Look at this place.  I never felt so conspicuous in my life.

speaker: Niles
text: You must simply try to blend in.  Fortunately, I haven't shaved in several hours.  You should loosen your tie.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, and you might try tucking in your watch fob.

speaker: Niles
text: That happens to be a Phi-Beta-Kappa key.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, then by all means, let it dangle.  Perhaps they have a local chapter.

speaker: Niles
text: Actually, this is quite stimulating in a lower-depths sort of way.  And I've always been something of a squalor buff.

speaker: Frasier
text: The only problem is, I don't see Daphne or Jimmy.

speaker: Niles
text: [_to bartender_] Excuse me.  Has a young woman been in here this evening, approximately five foot nine and three quarters, with skin the color of Devonshire cream and the sort of eyes that gaze directly into one's soul with neither artifice nor evasion?

speaker: Frasier
text: This would be an Englishwoman called Daphne.

speaker: Bartender
text: Ah yeah, the one who came in with Jimmy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Right.

speaker: Bartender
text: She was over there shooting pool a minute ago.  I think she stepped in the back.

speaker: Frasier
text: What happened to Jimmy?

speaker: Bartender
text: [_chuckles_] He tried to get fresh with her.  She threw a hammerlock on him and ran him out of here.  That babe can take care of herself.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_to Niles_] I told you so.

speaker: Bartender
text: And good riddance too.  Guy was no good.  I knew it the first time I saw him.  You can always tell.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yeah, yeah, yeah.  Come on Niles, we've taken our walk on the wild side, let's get out of here.

speaker: Niles
text: What about Daphne?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well come on, you heard what she did to Jimmy.  Think how mad she'll be if she should find us here.

speaker: Niles
text: You're right.  Best make ourselves scarce. [_Daphne comes out_] Good lord, there she is! _In an attempt to stop Daphne from seeing them, Frasier walks into a guy (Rocco) at the pool table, just as he's taking his shot._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, oh.  God, I am so sorry.

speaker: Rocco
text: Hey!  What the hell are you doing?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry, I was just trying to...

speaker: Rocco
text: You made me miss that shot.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry.

speaker: Rocco
text: I had two hundred bucks riding on that shot.

speaker: Frasier
text: Really sorry.

speaker: Rocco
text: [_to Niles, as his mate joins them_] Where do you think you're going?

speaker: Niles
text: Ah, I'll be back, I was just going to put another quarter in the meter.

speaker: Rocco
text: The meters don't run at night, and neither do you.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, that was rather an amusing play on words, you're a regular George S. Kaufman, we must tell our friends about this.

speaker: Rocco
text: You owe me two hundred dollars.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh well, I-I'd gladly pay you, but I-I don't have that kind of cash on me.

speaker: Niles
text: Even if he did, it would be absurd to bring it into a place like this.  You know, with the kind of element you might run into...

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles!  Maybe I could write you a check?

speaker: Rocco
text: My element don't take checks.  I think maybe we should take these guys outside, and wise them up.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I don't think that's really necessary at all.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh my goodness!  What are you two doing here?

speaker: Niles
text: We might ask you the same thing.  This happens to be one of our favorite haunts.  Actually, Maris and I had our rehearsal dinner here... the place was different then, it was more of a garden room and there was a trellis over there where the bar is...

speaker: Frasier
text: Shut up, Niles.

speaker: Daphne
text: You followed me, didn't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Daphne, we were worried about you.

speaker: Rocco
text: Excuse me, lady.  But it seems like your friends can't seem to come up with the two hundred they owe me, so I'm gonna have to uh - pardon my French - beat the crap out of them.

speaker: Frasier
text: Listen, listen.  I'm a psychiatrist, maybe we can talk this out in sessions.  You know, it seems that you have some control issues...

speaker: Rocco
text: Outside!

speaker: Daphne
text: WAIT!  I have money.  How would you like to go for double or nothing, sport?

speaker: Rocco
text: On what?

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, you look like a betting man. [_walks over to pool table_] I'll wager I can sink these five balls with a single shot. If I do, these boys are square.  If I miss, you double your money.

speaker: Rocco
text: Hey. I don't mind taking your money, but I was kinda looking forward to pulping this guy.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah, well.  We won't quibble. [_picks up cue_] If I miss, you can pulp him.  I'm feeling generous tonight.  I'll throw in the little one as well.

speaker: Niles
text: [_to Frasier_] What did she mean by that, "Throw in the little one?"  And what in God's name is "pulping"?

speaker: Rocco
text: You're on.  Okay.  But just to make sure this is on the up and up, let's use six balls.  Instead of sinking all five with one shot, [_rolling another ball onto table_] how about sinking all six?  Do that and uh, I'll forget the two hundred bucks.

speaker: Daphne
text: Fair enough. [_takes careful aim, then..._] Need a bit of chalk for me cue. [_lines up again, then..._] Does it matter in what order I make them?

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne!

speaker: Rocco
text: Hey lady.  If you make any of them, it'll be a miracle.

speaker: Daphne
text: Right.  Well... here goes nothing. _She takes the shot.  The scene goes into SLOW MOTION, and cliffhanger music plays...  As Frasier and Niles watch, on tenterhooks, five of the balls go down. They hug each other ecstatically and watch the cue ball roll toward the sixth.  It knocks the sixth toward the pocket... and it bounces out._

speaker: Daphne
text: RUN FOR IT!!! [_grabs the money_] _They race out of the bar and slam the doors behind them.  As Rocco and his buddies chase them, Daphne wedges her cue in the door handles. Frasier and Niles laugh and make "Nyah nyah!" faces before fleeing into the night with Daphne._
